description:
Let's Roll is THE spot to go for a tasty, beautiful, and loaded ice cream! They have interesting flavors such as Matcha and Ube and unlimited toppings to choose from (included in the price). It's super unique and fun to watch them make the ice cream rolls.

I recommend a combination of the Matcha roll with Raspberries and Mochi to top it off :)
author: Sydney G.

description:
Loved this place!  You can order different sizes.  I wished I ordered the large because my ice cream was THAT good.  

You can order something off the menu or customize your own.  I custom made mine with coffee ice cream, nutella, mochi, almonds and strawberries.  You get unlimited toppings!  Winning!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Given our recent move to China town not China town (ie the inner sunset) finally experiencing this rolled ice cream phenomenon was a must on the list. 

We stopped in (and were a little overwhelmed by the options) but this place did not disappoint. Essentially you choose from one of the pre determined mixes, or create your own and they put that plus what I assume was cream and sugar etc (melted ice cream) onto a freezing cold block and mix away. 

Your rolled ice cream then goes to the toppings person where you can add as many as desired. We were again overwhelmed and opted for only crushed graham cracker. 

Definitely better than cold stone and more fun, but kind of pricey at like $7 ea (given Andronico's is across the street and we could easily just go grab a pint).
author: Adele T.

description:
Just a block away from the famous San Tung. We decided to stop by for a quick dessert. Line was not long at all on a Wed afternoon. First thought was... pricey! But after seeing the staff make your custom order out of scratch, it's really understandable that you're paying for the labor and the experience. 
The ice cream itself was absolutely delicious. Tasted fresh and creamy. Loved it!! I got the 3 berries with as much toppings i could possibly fit. 
****also to the people leaving bad reviews because yall ice cream melted during delivery... ‍
author: Sarah G.

description:
My friend and I decided to satisfy our sweet tooth in Sunset area and came across Let's Roll on Yelp. Good reviews, check. Cute pics, check. Why not! 

The store was small and crowded, and there weren't any tables to chill at with your rolled treat. Luckily it was a nice day to go for a walk with ice cream! It is a "grab & go" type ice cream joint. The small sized ice cream was $6 (eek!), but it was a pretty large portion, and was creamy and delicious! You also have the option to add any toppings (included in the price), but they really can't fit many toppings on the ice cream so you are still somewhat limited in how hard you can go with the toppings. 

I ordered the cookies & cream flavored rolls and it was thick and tasty, and paired well with the toppings I ordered (rainbow Mochi, cheesecake bites, strawberry, and a cookie baton for a little extra crunch!).

Overall, 
-5 Stars: for presentation, the friendly staff, how quickly they made the rolled ice cream
-4 Stars: for flavor, for toppings galore
-2 Stars: for price (unreasonably high, even though this is San Francisco. Would rather get a $6 burrito because...well...burritos!).
author: Heather R.

description:
Rolled ice cream in the Sunset is a pretty solid spot for dessert after dinner. The line is sometimes long, but it moves pretty quickly. 

You choose a base and the toppings are unlimited. You choose them after the ice cream base is rolled! But the toppings didn't look that fresh IMO, they're sitting out and the fruits didn't look fresh, so I just got chocolate syrup on mine. The guy judged me hardcore for that but idc lol. 

10% OFF WITH YELP CHECKIN!
author: RachEl L.

description: Very good. Some of the young cashier can be a bit rude but overall the flavor is delicious
author: Craig L.

description:
The ice cream is delicious. I got the Cook Monster which is vanilla ice cream with an Oreo cookie chopped into it.  If you can, take the time to watch them make your rolls of ice cream. The ice cream is light. It didn't overwhelmed your taste buds and wasn't too sweet. I think it's a fun concept.  You can add as many toppings as you would like. 

Nice location in a descent area. You should grab your rolls and take a walk at the park.
author: Anita T.

description:
Wanted some dessert after San Tung so I pulled out my Yelp app and saw this place was only 1.5 blocks away. 

I've had rolled ice cream before so I wasn't expecting anything spectacular, but did like the fact they mixed flavors here. I ordered the Thai-Chee whcih is Thai iced tea and Lychee. We waited about 15 minutes since there were quite a few people ahead of us. 

The toppings are free and you can put whatever you want on there as long as it fits, which is pretty sweet. I added whipped cream, strawberry, pocky sticks and wafer rolls. 

I was pleasantly surprised with the combo of Thai iced tea and Lychee.. the flavors worked quite well together. The texture is definitely different than regular ice cream as it's much more dense.

I do recommend Let's Roll if you're into rolled ice cream. Plus free toppings!
author: Milton F.

description:
This such a cute place! 

Me and my friend had just finished exploring Golden Gate Park and were craving something sweet. We came across this place on yelp and saw it was walking distance as well so thought of trying it. 

Have to say absolutely amazing! I've never tried rolled ice cream and have to say this was delicious! 

Service was amazing, staff are very helpful on how to order. It is very busy so it did take some time to get my order but it was worth the wait. 

They offer unlimited toppings which is pretty cool! 

Parking would be very hard to find even though we walked.
author: Laksh M.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised at how nice the ice cream was! I saw videos about this style of "rolling" ice cream and I assumed it would be weird and icy instead of the classic creaminess that I like. 

I got the cookies n cream flavor and I loved it! It was very creamy but also not half way melted already like other ice cream places. The ice cream was firm when you scooped into it but melted nicely in your mouth :)

The only downside is that it takes a while to roll the ice cream, so I wouldn't go if there's a big line.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Oh, this place is unbelievable.

It's ice cream that they pound on a board for like 5 minutes straight and then cut up with knives and then roll up like bunch of fruit roll ups in a cup. There's toppings at the end too.

The place is slightly dumpy but not too bad.  Kind of like places on Taraval not inner Sunset.  It's like 8 bucks for each cup of ice cream roll ups.

Great break from watching TV.
author: Asper K.

description:
Ice cream smoothed out on a freezing pan and then carefully sculpted into tight rolls? Yes, please! The texture is surprisingly dense and decadent. Plus, Let's Roll lets you put on unlimited toppings! 

The only disappointment was that I didn't see a French bulldog with an eye-patch running around...

Tried: Funky Monkey - vanilla ice cream with bananas and Nutella topped with cocoa Krispies and condensed milk.
author: Dyanna Q.

description:
I came on a Monday afternoon and decided on a small thai-chee (thai tea/lychee flavored). Luckily, there were only 3 people in front of me, so I only waited around 10 minutes for my ice cream.

I liked the flavors and the fact that they give unlimited toppings! They have a bunch of toppings to choose from like fruits, sweets, jellies, and sauce/syrups. My favorites were the pocky, mochi, lychee jelly, and strawberries. I wish I could've added more toppings but my cup was pretty full already.

I can see how the line would take foreverrr because the rolling of the ice cream takes a while. I'd probably only come when the line isn't too bad!
author: Tara A.

description:
Located right next to San Tung so perfect if you're feeling some ice cream that's within walking distance. Would I consider this stand-out premium ice cream? Probably not but it is still decent ice cream. Keep in mind that rolled ice cream has a more tough texture compared to normal ice cream. Toppings are the standard toppings that you find at a froyo place: marshmallows, colored mochi, Oreos, Pocky, etc. Perk is that you can add as many topics as you want. 

The small bowl runs for around $5.50 and the large runs for about $7 so prices are on the pricier side but check in on good old Yelp for 10% off.
author: Kevin T.

description: Great spot, ice creak is good. Unlimited toppings which is such a plus for me. Customer service was very helpful aswell
author: Alli B.

description:
Been meaning to check this spot out for a long time now. Finally!!!! Swing by after a family dinner with my bros, sis-in-law, and their kids. Gotta finish up the wknd right, you know what I mean?! Lol! 

This time... I got Strawberries (which is vanilla ice cream + strawberries) and added graham crackers into the mix. Kept it simple and only added the peanuts and crushed Oreos and topped it off with a toasted marshmallow. Yumm!!!! The kids got a lot, a lot more toppings. Lol!   Definitely gotta come back and try other toppings.
author: Helen W.

description:
Don't get me wrong earthlings, I too love a good gimmick but I'm not particularly fond of long wait times.

I came in the day after Christmas around 9pm already knew what to expect taste wise because I had already tried Icicles in San Jose. Same concept: you pick your base ice cream as the vehicle to toppings of your choice. Toppings range from an assortment of cookies, cereals, candies, fruit, and drizzles. 

We ordered the Cookie Monster which was literally just a liquid white vanilla base with a single Oreo crush in. At first I thought maybe they were skimpy with the Oreo but I think it was fitting for a size small.

Added bananas, strawberries, pocky sticks, and white chocolate drizzle. I'd advise eating this as soon as you get it. We waited a bit and the ice cream was a little tough to spoon out, but it was delightfully tasting none the less.

Not sure I'd wait in line to order and wait for them to make it again (there's only two minions and work stations). I think I'll stick to the traditional scoop and go establishments for sake of time and impatience.
author: Connie M.

description:
So what's the hype!??


It was a hot summer day and the hubs and I wanted to find out. --But we weren't willing to stand in those crazy lines we've seen in downtown San Mateo. 

That's where Yelp came into play (of course!)

I found this spot, we drove over... walked in and there was no line. It was cool to watch how they make the rolled ice cream.

But one dilemma, as I ordered, the young man switched out with another worker... and I didn't know until later (when 2 people who ordered after got their orders before me) that the 2 workers didn't get my order AT ALL. And my husband already had his order, too... so, I went back to the register and said, "So, I don't think you got my order cos the other dude left and you took over... my husband got his ice cream as did 2 people after us, but my husband did pay for our 2 ice creams." 

They were apologetic, put my order in right away... fortunately, it doesn't take long to roll. 

Then, when I ate my ice cream it was okay. It's just the novelty of having rolled ice cream. It all tastes the same, 'of course' we thought. ‍

The toppings are free tho. So that's a plus. 
And no line. 

So, aside from forgetting to take my actual order, this place was fine. Young folks working which is fine but simple things like putting an order in is obviously important for your business.
author: Roxane P.

description:
LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT! LOVE IT!

As always, I was being a difficult customer and taking forever to decide on a flavor. Don't worry - I stepped aside for other people to order first. But the lady at the cashier was super patient and friendly. Before you choose the flavor though, you can get small or regular sizes.

I finally decided on the Matcha Cha - surprise surprise right? Well I was also debating between the Master Ube (vanilla with ube) and Smores (vanilla with chocolate and graham crackers). It was actually a hard decision!

After they create the ice cream roll masterpieces in front of your eyes, they let you add FREE AND UNLIMITED toppings! They have a super long selection to choose from and I LOVE it! I got the mochi, strawberries, and condensed milk. The colorful mochi was soft and chewy - just the way I like it. Not stale at all.

Anyway, the ice cream rolls were AMAZING! I had it before somewhere else and had a bad experience because the ice cream was bad - it had that gritty/sandy texture in it. But this was AMAZING. It was actually frozen ice cream. It didn't fall apart. It gets creamy in your mouth.

I'll definitely be going back for the other two flavors I wanted. Wait for me!
author: Athena C.

description:
When this place first opened up I thought it was just a Hype, seeing all those people lined outside the door...

Let me tell you this, I finally had it for the first time & it is the softest, most creamiest, and smoothest ice cream I ever had. 

The flavors are great and you get a variety of tasty topics to choose from. The price is pretty cheap too for such a creative way of making ice cream. 

Now that I think about it this place reminds me of "Nubis yogurt" haha. 

If you see the line outside the door, I don't recommend even getting in line. It takes some time for the workers to chop, spread & roll the ice cream. So the best time to get it is when it's fairly empty.
author: Yuriy T.

description:
Straight forward, there wasn't any lines but it took my entire party a little under 10 min to receive all 5 of our orders. (There were about 7 other people waiting for their orders) The toppings are unlimited and you pick your toppings after you receive your order. Lots to choose from! Once the rolled ice cream melts, it's like regular ice cream. A little pricey IMO but it does take a lot of labor to smash and roll the ice cream. The small cost $5.50 and regular cost $7.00 

I ordered the cookie monster aka cookies n' cream and this was the best cookies n' cream ice cream I have ever had in my entire life! It was so smooth, rich, and creamy. I couldn't decide which toppings to get, I was overwhelmed with all the options and the staffed recommended strawberry, bananas, and whipped cream. This was a great combo! :)
author: Annie Y.

description:
I'm so confused. 

I'm all about finding new ways to enjoy ice cream, unless those new ways involve me waiting 20 minutes crammed in between a bunch of sweaty teenagers on a basic park bench for ice cream that's in the shape of a fruit roll up. No amount of free toppings is going to make that fun. 

The whole shop was packed when I visited, and I had no idea what I was in for.  Just to give you an idea, I paid $5 something for cookies 'n' cream rolls. Okay, fair enough. I was given number 13. But when I sat down to wait, I quickly learned that they were on number 79! Ugh! 

If you know me, then you know I hate waiting, especially when the payoff isn't that exciting. There I was, just sitting there with my teeth in my mouth, wedged uncomfortably between the part of adolescence where one is blissfully unaware that he or she needs deodorant. 

Over 20 minutes later, I received my prize. I was confused. It's not like it was terrible, but I don't understand what the point is of serving ice cream in a roll. You can't unroll it. It's not like mochi, with a fun outer layer. It's just ice cream in the shape of a diploma. Once it melts, it's just like all other ice cream. 

I enjoy cute things but this is really a little nuts. Are we all really that bored that we want to wait 20+ minutes for an ice cream diploma? For teenagers, perhaps. For this girl, no. I like to be the hustler, not the hustlee.
author: Sunny S.

description:
This was a surprisingly great spot. I came on a Saturday night with friends. I'd never had ice cream rolls before, and while they looked cool, I was skeptical that they had the same density as regular ice cream. Boy, was I wrong!

They have a pretty solid assortment of choices for ice cream, not too many and not too few. They have a massive selection of toppings available as well. I opted for the Thai Chee. 

The only downsides to my visit were that the shop was quite small and it took quite a while for the ice cream to come out, and there weren't any good places to stand or sit available while I was waiting. Fortunately, I had friends to talk to, and it was cool watching the ice cream being made. 

The ice cream itself was fantastic. The Thai tea flavor was very authentic, and the lychee jelly pieces were a perfect complement. I even got more lychee jelly as a topping. Despite my worries, the ice cream rolls are very dense, even more so than normal ice cream scoops, and they look beautiful! The ice cream was smooth and creamy, almost like gelato.

It's definitely worth a visit!
author: Daniel M.

description:
I went here a few weeks ago and since it is new, I think they are still figuring out a few things. The menu is not as straightforward to someone that has never had this type of ice cream before; I think it would be helpful to have some simple "how to order" explanations on the signs or have staff be able to clearly explain it. 

I ordered the ube which was delicious and tasted surprisingly good! I will say I've been to other places where my ice cream was made faster; it seems like the waiting area can get crowded due to the amount of people waiting. Also, the staff seemed a bit distracted and confused when I went up to choose my toppings. 

While it probably is not most people's priority, it seemed like the shop was very quickly set up, and the ambiance / decor did not seem like the most professional or cleanly. Again, not a priority, but an observation I had. 

Otherwise, I enjoy having a new ice cream option around and will definitely come back once they have smoothed out their process a little.
author: Alyssa T.

description:
We live nearby and decided to stop by and try this place out. There is always a really long line here and I wanted to confirm what the hype was all about. 

In terms of positives, the staff is extremely helpful and friendly. I like that they have a nice selection of ice cream flavor options. The setup here is as efficient as possible. You order your ice cream flavor at the register, take a number and wait. The staff work tirelessly to get orders out with minimal wait time. Toppings are selected at the end once your order is ready and they take the care to get your order picture worthy. The ice cream texture is nice and creamy and not the least bit icy. 

In my numerous walkbys I have seen the owners scale up the number of frozen tables and staff from just a few to six tables so things move quickly enough. The main negative about this spot is that the preparation is by nature extremely time intensive so you will be in for a bit of a wait when you stop by. There is not much room for hanging out or dining in so this is a bit of a stand and eat treat. Also the interior is extremely warm so not a lot of incentive to hang out inside when it is hot out.
author: Alice H.

description:
Came here with le bf after having San Tung wings about a block or 2 away. This place had been on my bookmark list for a long time, ever since it opened, but because we rarely go that way for dinner, we have never gone. After going last night, I have a feeling we will be back more often. 

After contemplating the menu, both le bf and I got the small Cookie Monster (vanilla ice cream base with a crushed oreo). 

There was no line around 6:30pm! We walked right in and ordered. Because we were the only people in there, it only took about 3 minutes for our rolled ice cream to be made and to choose toppings (which were unlimited). I opted for mochi, whipped cream, almonds and strawberries. Le bf decided to top his with more oreos and mochi.  

We both had dinner right before we stopped by and we each thought that the small was pretty large in terms of food you get for the money. I suggest that if you come here with another person after having dinner, and can agree on 1 flavor and toppings, you should be fine just sharing 1 small. We both ended up throwing more than half of it away because we were just simply too full. No, it isn't the cheapest ice cream you are going to get in the city. However, for the amount you get to price ratio, for SF, this was a pretty good deal. 

We both really enjoyed how smooth the texture was. The ice cream itself also tasted really good. Le bf fell really quiet while he was eating his ice cream, which means he was truly having a moment with his ice cream. We both would come back, and the next time, I think we will just share one.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
The Thai rolled ice cream here tastes very good! It's a very inexpensive price for what you get especially since you can have unlimited toppings!

It's a little hole in the wall type place, no AC when I went, VERY busy with a long line, although a bit understaffed they were.  
The wait was worth it though because I have complaints about the taste or quality of their ice cream :) 
The workers worked hard at their job and you can tell they wanted to try to get everyone through as quick as possible.
author: Tori G.

description:
Got the strawberry cheesecake and It was delicious! Def satisfied my sweet tooth. The ice cream wasn't heavy and you can choose whatever toppings you'd like.
I will certainly be back!
author: Tania M.

description: Getting rolled ice cream for the first time after all the hype. The nitrogen plate is pretty cool, but then again, it's still just ice cream. I ordered the rocky roll, and it's basically just chocolate ice cream mixed with a couple of nuts. On the other hand, I was surprised that the ice cream didn't melt as fast as I thought it would. Favorite part: the unlimited toppings.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Mixed feelings about this place. I think it really depends who you get to serve you. Some "rollers" are better than others.
author: Erica C.

description: Yummy. Delivery is fine. You should eat it right away. Cookie Monster n salted Carmel are great.
author: Wildkatz D.

description:
40 minute wait on a Saturday afternoon for our ice cream to be ready and they made one of our orders wrong so it was another 10 minutes. 

You pay at the front near the entrance as you walk in, then wait at the benches for them to make your order. All toppings are free and you can get as many different ones as you want. 

The actual ice cream was decent: we got the Thai Chee (Thai iced tea ice cream with lychee) which was a bit too sweet for me and the strawberry shortcake which the bf enjoyed. 

Overall fine but wouldn't come here again. There are better rolled ice cream places in the city (eg. Steep).
author: Dani T.

description: My family loves this place! The ice cream is delicious and they have lots of creative combinations. I love the pretzel and salted caramel. Rolled ice cream is always a great show! They're list of unlimited toppings is extensive and creative. It's not "cheap", but you don't go to an artisan ice creamery for cheap ice cream. You go for the quality, the superior taste and texture, the cleanliness and efficiency, and in the case of rolled ice cream, the entertainment. Portions are generous; quality and presentation are top notch. Line can sometimes be long, but it moves fast.
author: Jenn E.

description:
The famous Rolled Ice Cream with an expensive price tag.

The popular rolled ice cream makes another strike in San Francisco. Located in the populated Irving Street near Golden Gate Park, Let's Roll Ice Creamery is an ice creamery where you get to see your ice cream made in front of your very own eyes.
I came with a friend at around 1 pm on a Saturday, where it was packed. I waited around 30 minutes to get my ice cream.

Let's Roll has several flavors that you can choose from. Any serving of ice cream is around ~$8. I personally chose the Matcha Ice Cream, but there is a wide selection of flavors.

One big problem that I have with Let's Roll is that they do not tell you when your ice cream is being made. It may be a problem when the store is crowded, but no employee told me that my ice cream was being made. I personally believe a large reason that these Ice Cream Rolls are popular is because it is very awesome to watch your ice cream being made.

The Ice Cream itself was good. I don't believe that it was artisan level ice cream, but the Matcha Ice Cream was still delicious. A big component of this style of ice creamery is the unlimited toppings. How the toppings work is: you ask the employee whatever toppings you want. If you want more, then you would have to ask the employee in your first trip to the toppings. In my opinion, I believe there should be a topping station for the customers(For things such as cereal, chocolate chips, nothing complicated).

While the quality of everything is good, the outrageous price and the lack of viewing experience definitely makes this place somewhere I don't want go back to for awhile.
author: Anthony Y.

description:
Love Love Love!!! I tried Let's Roll a few months ago when I first moved to San Francisco, and I have been addicted since!  It is a very unique method of making ice cream that somehow produces ice cream that tastes higher in quality and creamier than most other types.

You are able to customize your order to include or remove any toppings. Lots of flavor combinations to choose from. Overall, a great spot if you are looking to try something new. I have taken all of my friends here and every one of them has loved this spot!
author: Ani S.

description:
Cool concept but I've had better.

Ordered the matcha; good and not icey, however it was a little too sweet for me. I like how  they give you unlimited toppings. My sister ordered the funky monkey, which was cool but I don't like banana.

Service could be better, feels drab. Pricey for a cup of rolled ice cream too.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
The first place I have ever tried rolled ice cream - and has me hooked for the rest of my days. 

If it weren't for the slow service, I would give this place 5 stars because the ice cream was GREAT! Basically, if you come here, prepare to wait a while and expect some kind of line. In my case, it was worth it. 

I forgot the name of my order, but it was vanilla ice cream with caramel and salted pretzels. SUCH A GREAT COMBO. It was mixed and rolled perfectly because I still enjoyed the crunchy texture of salted pretzels and hints of smooth, sweet caramel just enough in every bite. The best thing about this spot that I realize that other spots don't always do - unlimited added toppings! And so many to choose from including different cereals, fruit, cookies, candy, etc. Plus, their menu of flavors is very extensive and has great combinations - something to satisfy everyone's taste.

If you're in the area, you've got time to kill, and ice cream is just what you need, GO!!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
We got the ice cream delivered which may have impacted things.
I didn't really get the appeal of the rolling ice cream technique - maybe it is cool to watch them make?

The Cookie Monster was pretty good. Enjoyed that one.
The Carmel Vanilla ice cream (whatever it is called) was pretty bad - my girlfriend couldn't finish it and threw it out. She doesn't like very sugary things though so maybe that was the issue.

Overall we thought the price was good and at least I was pleased with the end result. Nothing too special but a solid option.
author: Tyler C.

description:
Nice for pictures but not that great!

Came here thursday almost at 1:00pm(time that they open) and about 4 people waiting. They did not open till 1:05pm which was a tad disappointing since they open at 1:00pm.

Limiting seating. Minimal decor inside.

Price:$7.05 for anything on their menu including unlimited free toppings.

It took about 20 mins for us to get our order with only 4 people ahead of us. Making the ice cream is time consuming so it makes sense it took a while for us to get our order. 

They don't give you that much topping so if you want more of a topping you should ask for extra!!

Order: Thai-chee, it was milky, lychee was very prominent and tasty! 

Overall it's a cute place, concept, nice to take a picture but it's not something I would be craving or going back to frequently.
author: Michele G.

description:
Rolled ice-cream?? I couldn't imagine what that looks and tastes like so I had to give it a try. 

The shop is really small. There was a line to order your ice-cream, and then you have to squeeze in and find a place against the wall to wait for your ice-cream to be made. I can't imagine what it will be like when they get busier, and the line will be out the door. 

We ordered the 3x's Berries, and the Matcha-Cha. I like the quirky names of the ice-creams. Both ice-cream were  very good! I was especially impressed by the way they were made. This unique style makes the ice-cream dense and it doesn't melt that fast. 

They offer Free and unlimited toppings! Where else can you go and get an offer like that? I will definitely come back for more. I had my eye on the Thai Chee.
author: Edie G.

description:
Thai rolled ice cream in SF. 

Fun concept and fun to watch, but long lines and lack of creative flavors with a high price tag make it a little less exciting. 

The bf ordered the ube flavor. Once you've placed your order, you slowly move down the queue and can watch as workers mix, mash then roll your ice cream. Once completed, you're allowed unlimited free toppings per order - free toppings!!! And cups come in two sizes.

Space is small, cramped with little seating. Also on a warm day expect a line out the door. That will also come with a longgggggg wait. We had two people in front of us and still had a 10-15 minute wait time. 

Downside is there are no dairy-free alternatives.
author: Mandi W.

description: Fun night watching them pour mash, mix, and roll your ice cream. With unlimited toppings this is a kids paradise.
author: cory h.

description:
3.5 stars

Love the concept, and these workers work hard to deliver this type of ice cream with all the scraping and chopping, but the ice cream is just okay to me compared to the two rolled ice cream experiences I had in Manhattan's Ten Below Ice Cream and Juicy Spot. 

How it works: go to the cashier, order, take a number, and wait.

There are lots of flavors to choose from here and unlimited toppings (yay!) Today I chose the thai tea flavored one while my friend got the strawberry. Price is $6.50/cup. Love that toppings are unlimited, but some were out when I ordered today. The workers work hard, and you can watch the whole process, so it's fair.

The wait was about half an hour. Overall, I would come back if it is convenient and the line isn't long.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Delicious and artistic!
Fast service even with long lines
author: Diana B.

description:
Finally! A rolled ice cream joint in the city that's actually doin' it right! Strawberry Cheesecake is my favorite so far (also tried 3x Berry, Cookie Monster &  Thai Chee) but this is subject to change since I plan on trying all the flavors within the next few months lol.

Perhaps I went on the luckiest day ever (gloomy SF Saturday 4/22, 3PM) as there was no long line forming out the door, no 20+ minute wait to get my ice cream and the workers weren't skimping out on their unlimited toppings (as claimed to be all opposite by other Yelpers.) 

But even with my great experience, I definitely understand that a long line and a 20+ min wait IS to be expected and I'm well aware that I'm bound to eventually wait on my future visits- Thats just how it is at all *GOOD* rolled ice cream places (ex: Icicles in San Jose, 10Below in NYC.) 

Let's Roll- y'all nailed it!!! But please do consider having MOCHI and BOBA as part of your unlimited toppings- it would be a hit ;)
author: Ingrid E.

description:
Not many ice cream parlors risk having this meticulous methodical and artisan style creation. Yes you'll wait, but the aesthetics put in to your delicacy are worth it. May be you can't  withstand the wait, perhaps in a hurry- okay then don't come here! Rollup with patience and you'll rollout satisfied.  
We came here excited to see the creation and reluctant to taste the ice cream. However the flavors were tasty!


Most of the cream flavors are distinguished, unique, even an oddity to a typical ice cream shop. Don't come in expecting something quotidian like vanilla. Maybe come here drunk without inhibitions.  Or open minded. Whatever 

We tried the purple yam and the strawberry cheesecake. Cashiers favorite. Now our favorite. We loved watching the creation process. Man those guys should  have huge forearms with all the machine gun fast chopping they do. 

Very small area. Super packed because most people were gleaning over the creators even after obtaining their ice cream. 


They have FUHHREEEE TOPPINGS. I repeat FREEE TOPPINGS.

Overall 15$ with tip but we were very happy. Best novelty ice cream between 9th and Funston
author: Rob C.

description:
We just had to try it once knowing we'd probably never be back. The thai rolled ice cream trend has been appearing all over the Bay Area lately. Surprisingly, I never tried it when I lived in SJ. Walked in and there were crowds of people waiting for their order. 

They have a little stand up menu at the entrance with several combos they've created from either thai tea, matcha, or vanilla ice cream I believe. It would've been nice to have listed what types of ice creams were in each design.. Anyways, my boyfriend and I shared a cookie monster (vanilla ice cream + oreo cookie). Unlimited toppings, but I'm not a huge fan of toppings on my ice cream so I only asked for strawberries. It took about 30 minutes for us to get our order. They were so backed up with orders, it was crazy. Kudos to the guys making the ice cream rolls though.. it was nonstop work for them! 

There's really nothing special about these ice cream rolls except for the fact that they are freshly made and rolled up. They appear a little more frozen compared to regular scooped ice cream, but that's necessary to keep the shape. Ours tasted like any ordinary cookies n cream ice cream. 

It was $6.50 (they had a promo going on). You're paying that price to get photo worthy ice cream and to pay for the labor that goes into making into these rolls! Honestly, I'd rather get a scoop of ice cream elsewhere and avoid the long wait.

They definitely need to hire more staff to keep up with this craze.
author: Sydney C.

description:
This place used to be JJ ice cream I believe; now they make the viral Thai rolled ice cream. It took about 20-30 minute to order and get the ice cream. It's 6.50 each, with free unlimited toppings. I wanted the ube but was told they ran out, so we tried the matcha and strawberry, matcha can be skipped, strawberry was good because it had fresh berries chopped in. The consistency of the ice cream was hard, it'd be much easier to eat if instead of a white plastics spoon they gave you the short wooden ice cream spoons. 

Definitely worth coming once to try it for the experience and for a photo, but don't expect great ice cream. I've since learned that these ice cream rolls can easily be replicated at home with a frozen skillet or stone from the freezer, so the next time I eat ice cream rolls it'll probably come from my kitchen.
author: Long C.

description:
Walked by one day and decided to finally give the whole rolled ice cream fad a try. I LOVE my ice cream so it doesn't take much to make me happy when it comes down to it. But waiting 40 minutes on a Friday afternoon at 2pm is not my thing. Food does not taste better to me if I have to wait so long to get it. Since it's a small place after ordering you kinda get pushed in a corner or have to be super close to other people. The one spot in the corner I waited near had a stool which was nice but it was away from the guys actually doing the rolling so I never actually got to see the "magic happen". I hear that's the main reason people come here. 

Once you order they give you a number. It costs $6.50 for the roll and you can get as many toppings as you like but they keep it minimal. I had the Thai chee with lychee and strawberry(only 1 piece given), condensed milk(very small amt), pocky sticks( I had to ask for 2 twice), cookie stick, whipped cream( a dollop) and rainbow sprinkles. I would ask for more since the toppings don't make it very long. The rolls stay colder longer so that's nice for less meltage while eating it. It was good but I won't be waiting in line again for an experience I can easily get elsewhere since I don't need fancy like this. Cool concept though. It has gotten skeptical people like myself to try it out so that's impressive.
author: Bhavisha P.

description:
We were walking around the area waiting for our table at izakaya sozai and came across this place. We've been wanting to try rolled ice cream for awhile and was super excited to try it. There were a lot of people around 6:30pm on a Saturday but since the wait for izakaya sozai was an hour, we thought it would be a good idea to wait here and enjoy our ice cream before getting some ramen. Although the line was pretty long, we thought it would be a max of 20 minutes wait time, but nope! We waited for about an hour and ended up missing our table while waiting for the ice cream :( 

Luckily we were able to get the next table available at izakaya sozai. But just a warning, the ice cream rolls are pretty good, but be prepared for a wait! We ordered the Cookie Monster and added strawberry pocky sticks and condensed milk. I believe the toppings are unlimited. We both really enjoyed the taste of the ice cream rolls, just kind of disappointed in the hour-long wait. I will definitely come back though! Maybe when I'm waiting for a table at a restaurant nearby or if I have some extra time to spare. Hope they work on their service and speed it up a little! The system was a little confusing and they kind of got the order numbers mixed up, but they're new so I'm sure they're working on that.

**TLDR?
The ice cream rolls are really good, but be prepared for a wait! Came here around 6:30pm on a Saturday and waited for an hour! But if you do happen to be in the area and have some extra time to spare, try the Cookie Monster! :)
author: Bailey L.

description:
Be prepared to wait. This place is worth trying (at least once). The novelty is fun and the actual flavors are pretty darn intense. Not something you would expect. Storefront is pretty cramped though inside so if you're claustrophobic, I'd recommend waiting outside.

The menu is set already and you have a variety of flavors to try from. I ordered the "mocha matcha" which is matcha & cream. The workers actually making the ice cream get a decent arm work out each time. They're mashing up the ingredients and spreading it over the machine until the mixture freezes. At which point they scrape up the ice cream and roll it into 6-7 pieces. The amount may not seem like much but when you're eating it, it's actually quite filling. I almost finished mine. Almost.

In any case, after it's all neatly stacked in a cup, it goes down to the assembly line where an assortment of unlimited free toppings await you (sauces, fruits, cookies, nuts, etc). I opted for pocky sticks and an Oreo cookie.  The store should provided heftier spoons. These plastic ones are barely cutting it. Almost snapped mine in half just trying to eat the ice cream which is quite dense.

I contemplated whether the wait was worth it. I mean, why wait for a ridiculous amount of time for ice cream when you can get ur dessert instantly at a regular ice cream shop? Well, the ice cream texture here is def different. Not quite so creamy and soft but the flavors are intense. Tried my friends' Thai Chew and Cafe Ole and oh my, each one was amazing! 

I would def come back but probably during the weekdays when it's not so crowded.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Last Saturday, I tried to go to Icicles' new location in Cupertino and the line was [not surprisingly] out the door and wrapped around the corner. While they broke my Thai Ice Cream Rolls cherry last year in San Jose and I thoroughly enjoyed my first Thai Ice Cream Rolls experience, there was no way I was waiting up to 2 hours for it again for a novelty dessert.

So, we settled for froyo at Yogurtland in the same plaza, and all was good until the beezie in front of me sneezed INTO the toppings bar. She didn't even attempt to turn her head, she sneezed into the oreo's bin like it was nothing. While me eyes gave her the evil stare down, my thunder thighs thanked her - they did NOT need all those oreo filling. 

I heard that Let's Roll Ice Creamery (formerly JJ Ice Cream) started to serve Thai Ice Cream Rolls these week so decided to pay a visit before word gets outs. I visited on a weeknight and there was no one in line when I ordered but since everything is made to order expect each order (from ordering to finish product) to take about 5 minutes a person. Bench seating only.

They currently have 8 flavors: Nutella & Banana, Thai Tea & Lychee, Berries, Oreo Cookie, Coffee, Matcha, Bacon & Syrup, and Ube (Purple Yam). You receive 6 ice cream rolls with unlimited toppings for $6.50 this week. Regular price is $7. If you don't want to wait for the Ice Cream Rolls, they have Bud Ice Cream for $1.95/scoop. CC's accepted. Stamp card available. 

If you've never had Thai Ice Cream Rolls before, it's a cool process to watch. A milk concoction is poured onto an iced grill, smoothed across the surface until it stiffens, and is scraped into ice rolls. Then, it's crowned with your choice of toppings. They don't have the toppings listed or labeled but they have over 10 sauces/syrups like condensed milk, caramel, chocolate, etc. and over 20 toppings like pocky, wafers, sprinkles, oreos, etc. Thank you for keeping the toppings covered!

I ordered the #8 Master Ube ($6.50): http://bit.ly/2oMCDP2 with a condensed milk drizzle, pocky, and added fruity pebbles as suggested by one of the kind staff. Great suggestion as the fruity pebbles gave a nice crunchy texture contrast. 

I loved Icicles and STEEP Creamery's Thai Ice Cream Rolls but I wasn't loving this one. The ice cream rolls didn't maintain its shape so it was just like eating scooped ice cream. Part of the draw of Thai Ice Cream Rolls may be the theatrics of making it but I enjoy the sensation of the creamy roll melting in my mouth. It's a different texture and mouthfeel than plain 'ol scooped ice cream. I didn't get that here. They do give you an ample portion though so it's good for sharing. 

The employees are really nice and it's obvious that they're trying their best, especially the ice cream rollers which have the toughest job of handcrafting each order. I appreciate that they wear sanitary face masks. Very hygienic. 

If you have little hoomans, Let's Roll would be a great place to take them so they can marvel at their ice cream rolls being made in front of them. But, for those looking for artisan quality with housemade toppings/puddings, I think STEEP Creamery is a better option in San Francisco.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Rolled ice cream is fun to try but the craze melts away just as quickly. I came here after a birthday dinner celebration for dessert because you what's a celebration without some additional calories? 

They have a black board that displays all the flavors and after some back and forth, I settled on the s'mores for myself. My reason being I would already get to sample some of my friends' flavors; bless their hearts. If you haven't heard, rolled ice cream starts off as regular ice cream that gets smashed with some cream on a ice plate. The ice cream artists will then scrape it up into sections that look like a roll, place it in a little cup let you add toppings. I chose fruity pebbles because I can. Also added a straw biscuit because I'm adventurous.  It was good but I would still prefer regular scoops on a waffle cone.

That being said, be prepared to wait if you go at peak times. There's only a few employees who can roll up some ice cream and even fewer stations to do so. Get the ube one because that's actually worth the wait.
author: Quoc N.

description:
They just started serving rolled ice cream this week so there are some kinks that need to be worked out. 

Just FYI, if this is your first time getting rolled ice cream, it's more expensive ($6.50-$7), takes longer (took ~20mins for me), and one can be easily split by at least 2 people.

First, you start by ordering and paying right inside the door. The full list of rolled ice cream flavors are on a board on the floor. There were a lot of people and there wasn't always a person at the front with the tablet to get your order so one couple actually didn't know they had to order near the door beforehand. There are no signs or anything showing the process. 

After, you wait for your number to be called. They'll call your number to show that your ice cream is being made at one of the two stations if you want to watch or if they have any questions for you. Then either they give it to someone to help you put on toppings or they'll hand it directly to you to bring to a worker to put toppings on for you (another kink). I'd rather not have to get someone's attention to hand them my ice cream for toppings. 

Lastly, you choose whatever toppings you want. Another kink is that they don't have a full list or any labels on their toppings so you kinda have to guess what they have. They have condensed milk, chocolate syrup, pocky sticks, oreos, Graham crackers, sprinkles, and more. It didn't seem like there was a limit which was nice? Or maybe there is one and I just didn't hit it. We only asked for 2-3 toppings on ours. It took about 20 mins for ours to get made. 

We got the Cookie Monster and the Cafe Ole but I only tried the Cookie Monster. I thought it was pretty good. I've only had rolled ice cream once before so for my second time, it was not bad. Very frozen. It took longer to melt and eat than my first experience but I guess it's nice that it doesn't melt fast!
author: Amanda L.

description: Good stuff. Fresh. Go for the cheesecake topping. That's the best! Freshly made ice cream rolls. As good as dryers ice cream. Maybe better with the toppings.
author: Jack L.

description:
First, pick which flavor you like then order, pay and wait for your number to be called. Once they call your number you'll get  to decide what toppings to add! 

BEST PART IS UNLIMITED TOPPINGS!

I got the Thai lychee rolls with strawberry, straw, blueberries and drizzled in condense milk!
author: Cyndi L.

description: This place was so much fun the taro ice cream was perfect but the customer service just sucked. Nobody was friendly and the staff had an attitude like they didn't want to be spoken to at all. If you can get your ice cream to go... you probably should.
author: Angela M.

description:
Came in last night hoping to experience "rolled ice cream for the first time". There was a bit of a line and I was looking at the menu trying to decide what I wanted. During this time, the gentleman at the toppings area sneezed (he had no gloves on at the time) and then put gloves on and proceeded to put toppings on little girl's ice cream cup" WITHOUT WASHING HIS HANDS FIRST.

Some of you may not be bothered by this, but personally, I want to make sure people are being as hygienic as possible in food service (especially during cold season).

(I ended up walking out and not ordering anything after seeing this). BE WEARY!
author: Attiana P.

description: Amazing concept and creative way of making fresh and delicious ice creams. Loved all their flavors. Highly recommend.
author: Devan K.

description:
After seeing a billion rolled ice cream videos on Facebook, I finally had a chance to try this food craze and it was... not what I expected. 

When you see the ice cream being rolled, it looks super thin but in reality, it's VERY dense. Was not expecting to get so full off of this ice cream! 

I got the Cookie Monster (Oreos + Vanilla) with a bunch of different toppings. The toppings are definitely a plus, although they could be labeled better or have better signage explaining what they are. 

Aside from the rolled form, the ice cream itself tasted pretty standard imo.. Once I started eating it, it reminded me of Coldstone ice cream -- dense & thick! 

Service was struggling a bit bc there was a long line and although they had about 5 workers, it still takes time getting these orders out. The setup was a little cramped too -- a bunch of people (including myself) wanted to see the ice cream being rolled but there's not much room inside. 

Overall, thought it was worth a try, but not a go-to place for me!
author: Greg J.

description:
Finally, I got myself some rolled ice cream! After finally having an excuse to go here, I dragged a couple of friends along with me (definitely helps that one of them lives the block over). I at first thought that rolled ice cream was just hype and that it'd be like regular ice cream. I couldn't have been more wrong!

I ordered the strawberry cheesecake, and it was amazing! It was quite busy when we went in, but it was quite entertaining watching them make the ice cream. I ordered the small, which was possibly more than I anticipated, in a good way. It tasted very much like strawberry cheesecake and was quite filling. The best part was that I was able to choose the toppings for it at the end, and it didn't seem like there were any limits!

If you're in the area, I definitely recommend coming here!

Food: 8/10
Staff: 8/10
Atmosphere: 8/10
Value: 8/10
Overall: 8/10
author: Evan K.

description: Call me a trader but I love this place! Lol my bf's sister works at a different rolled ice cream shop but in my defense i discovered this place first and it "rolled my heart away!"
author: veronica s.

description: Delicious ice cream and unlimited toppings! Also fun to watch them make the ice cream. Great find!
author: Kyla T.

description:
I'm not a big fan of ice cream in actuality, but I've been finding myself craving this place so much recently! There's usually quite a line here and if you try this place - you'll definitely understand why! Something about their ice cream is extremely addicting! It's like they put crack seasoning it there (in the most harmless way!). 

Small will run you about $5 while a regular will run you about $7. The top flavors for me to try here are the ube and the thai tea (with lychee!). I had the thai tea one the other day and it was just lovely - happiness all around! We split a regular between three people since we did have dinner coming up, and I'm pretty sure I could have consumed that whole cup myself (and plan on doing this soon!). Toppings are unlimited - and range from cereals, to asian snacks (chocolate wafers, pocky, mochi!), to roasted marshmallows and a huge array of fruit! You can watch as they make your ice cream fresh through the glass panes and the staff are so nice and friendly when I'm piling on as many toppings as possible! The staff actually asked us if we wanted three roasted marshmallows and wafers (which would never fit in the cup)! So sweet!  The quality of ice cream here is really good too. If you've ever had ice cream fall apart to goop if you don't eat it quickly enough, be prepared for the complete opposite. You thoroughly enjoy the entire experience of thick, cold, flavorful ice cream, virtually melt free! 

My favorite toppings are mochi (you HAVE to have mochi), an assortment of fruit, and cap'n crunch. You can ask them for more of any item if you'd like and they will do it so don't be shy. Much of my happiness comes from the combo of ice cream and mochi so I must have a bunch! 

Some benches are available in one corner of the store, but probably only fit about 10 - 12 people max! It hasn't been too crowded though where I can't find a seat with my friend(s), after all, how long does it take to consume delicious rolled ice cream?! Golden Gate Park is pretty close by if you want to stroll off the deliciousness after! Will definitely be back!
author: Deanna S.

description:
This place's saving grace is the unlimited toppings, but everything else about this place left a little bit to be desired. The flow of traffic from ordering to where you watch getting your ice cream get rolled to where you select your toppings is really awkward and makes already long lines seem even longer. Not a whole lot that can be done about the small space, but it just seemed like the flow could've been designed better.

As for the ice cream itself, the ice cream is extremely dense despite being in rolled form and I found myself getting full pretty quickly. The taste was alright and the integration of some toppings into the ice cream base itself was also okay. Have definitely had better at other places.

Another Instagram food trend that delivers high on aesthetic, but not on taste.
author: John P.

description:
Expensive. No flavor. 
Today I had to wait forever because one of the guys (the only asiatic one) that was chatting and chatting with another girl (she was chatting but working at the same time) stopping to drink water, stopping to see what's going on outside...taking all the time in the work!
Not coming back. Not recommending it.
author: Masama S.

description: I had to wait an hour for my ice cream, I walked around like every other store possible in the area and it was pretty cold. There's also not much parking around. I didn't think any of the ice cream combinations sounded good but eventually chose the berry one. But they were out of like some key ingredients and offered alternatives. I think this place just got really popular so I'd give them a few months while they figure out ingredients/staffing and taste, and then it'll be better.
author: Apoorva D.

description:
After a failed attempt at going to the beach on Saturday, we instead decided to grab ice cream. We didn't want just any ice cream, no. No, we didn't. We wanted ROLLED ice cream. So, I popped open Yelp and found Let's Roll nearby. 

The heat was intense outside and inside this establishment. Our order took about 20 minutes or so because everybody and their momma (literally) had the same idea. The employees looked a hot sweaty mess as did the customers, but when ice cream is involved perspiration takes a back seat. 

I love that you can get an unlimited amount of toppings. I ordered the Chocoholic in a small ($6) size cup, which was actually a decent size, that consists of a mix of vanilla ice cream with brownie and then I added strawberries, whipped cream, and chocolate sauce as my toppings. It was yummy treat that fulfilled my want to be cooled down from the heat. 

TL:DR: The employees are pleasant, the ice cream is good, and I will likely go back if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Kevin B.

description: The menu is simple just like all the other rolling ice cream places, but you get a choice of small or large. I got the cookie monster which was vanilla with oreo cookies. They call your number when it is time to choose your topping, which you can choose unlimited of. There is seating inside and one bench outside. I felt that the whole process was out of order and the outside could have used more benches for people to lounge around.
author: Shelley L.

description:
How's the ice cream? Pretty decent. They have pre-made flavors in milk form, then they roll them out for you and add all the toppings you want at no extra cost. The wait? Kind of ridiculous. I understand it's new, so everyone wants to try it. They had 3 workers making the ice cream at a time and I had to wait about an hour for mine. 

Was it worth the wait? Probably not. Maybe I'm picky since I've had it in Thailand, where it originated. The flavors are mixed with plain milk and created per order there. It would take a long time there as well. 

To sum it up, if there's only a few people WAITING, then go for it. If there are people waiting AND there's a line, you may want to prepare yourself for a bit of a wait or come back another time. I'm still glad this type of place is opening up in SF, but the process can be better.
author: Aaron Y.

description: I've never been a fan of insanely sweet ice cream like the Cookie Monster but I am in love with their coffee, matcha and taichee ice cream. It has a strong taste, which I love, but it's also not too sweet that it'll make you gag. Also, the little rolls make eating it a little less messy.
author: Emily F.

description:
RIP, JJ Ice Cream.

Let's Roll is one of the latest of Thai ice cream roll places to hit San Francisco. Here's the concept: skilled ice cream scoopers skillfully mash and mix your ice cream into little rolls, cup them, and add toppings. It's a sight to behold. You've seen the videos online, right? (example: http://imgur.com/gallery/ckRFA)

For $8 ($7.95 before tax) a piece, it's basically a glorified Cold Stone Creamery--that is, ice cream, customizeable toppings, and a show. I do appreciate the unlimited toppings, though. The number of bases you can choose from is limited (and may be more limited than you expect--no matcha, no ube when I went), and they "roll" a limited amount of ingredients into the actual ice cream rolls, which tbh makes it a little less impressive. After they're finished rolling, they call you up and ask you which toppings you want. Don't get me wrong, the rolling is a spectacle to behold, and definitely adds depth to the flavor of the ice cream. I think it would be a little better if they used a creamier ice cream to add some softness though (although it might compromise the integrity of the rolls? idk I'm no ice cream expert).

After getting one of our orders wrong (asked for a Cookie Monster & a S'mores, got two S'mores), it felt like the employees were implying we were lying by showing us that they rang up S'mores x2. I was sure that our order was repeated back to us when we ordered, and I didn't really mind the mistake, but it didn't feel very good to get the blame deferred to me.

Other things:
- Love that there is an area strictly for viewing the "rolling show," behind glass and all.
- Price tag seems to be growing. A while back it was ~$7 a cup, now it's ~$8.
- Beware of the loud high school crowd.
author: Jade V.

description:
So I've always wanted to try Ice Cream rolls because I kept seeing pictures of it everywhere on social media. My first time ever having Ice Cream rolls was here at Let's Roll. 

MY EXPERIENCE:

It's a really small shop. When I say small, I mean "you can only take a few steps into the shop". The place was packed when I went, but there were only like 9 people. 

You order right when you walk into the shop and then they give you a ticket with numbers on it after you purchase your order. I ordered the 3x Berries. I had to squeeze my way through people to see them make my ice cream rolls. It was interesting just watching them prepare and make the rolls. I feel like it's a very important experience when you get ice cream rolls for the first time. 

After your ice cream rolls are done being made, they call out your number when ready. You then get to pick out toppings. They had a whole board of toppings. I was really surprised at how many toppings there were. I got the raspberry sauce with strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, and whip cream! They say you can have as many toppings as you want. Which is pretty cool. 

I really didn't know what to expect when I took a bite out of my ice cream rolls. I thought it wouldn't be creamy enough because it was thin and made on an ice cold metal surface. But I was wrong! It tasted creamy and had a great flavor. Personally I really liked it. The toppings made it even better. 

My overall experience was good. I have no complaints except for the size of the shop. It was just too small for how popular it is. I came here a second time and it was still packed. I ordered the same thing. It was still good to me! It's a nice dessert snack on a warm sunny day!
author: Tiger Y.

description:
Nice little Corner rolled ice cream shop.

 Randomly stopped by on a cold and foggy day in the bay to satisfy my sweet tooth. Decided to get the "thai Chee" thai tea flavor infused with lychee. Amazing flavor combo. 

Unlimited and free toppings!!! 

Negative star for Ice cream was a bit too hard in texture for my liking and for customer service of employees (18-23) in age yelling in Chinese while I am trying to enjoy my ice.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Currently obsessing about this place! Loving the new take/concept on how you view your traditional ice cream. Friendly staff, awesome vibe, great flavors plus unlimited free toppings. What more can you ask for? Five star well deserved. 

*must try: funky monkey, strawberry cheesecake & ube master*
author: Hanna L.

description: I love their ice Cream! Free toppings as much as you want, just once. It's great!
author: Vanessa W R.

description: It's a very cool idea! I don't think there are many rolled ice cream places in this area. Line out the door when there are 2 people ahead so I'm sure the line is out the door pretty often. I had the Cookie Monster which is vanilla based with Oreos. I really like that this place gives you unlimited toppings so we topped it off with crushed Oreos, whole Oreo, almonds, mochi, pretzels, and a toasted marshmallow that they torched! I think it's a very cool idea but I don't see a big difference of this in texture (when you get a scoop it kind of looks like regular ice cream) and a regular scoop of ice cream. I will say it is fun to watch them make rolled ice cream, it also takes a while to make it and that's why the line is so long.
author: Kylie L.

description: This was my first time having rolled ice cream, so I was really excited to see what the fuss was all about. I got the chocolate cookies and cream and I have to say that was the best $8 I've ever spent. It was unlimited toppings, but I only got a few because the cup was pretty small. I will probably come back for a quick dessert because it is quite fun to watch them make the ice cream from scratch.
author: Merrilyn W.

description: A super cool concept and the ice cream is really good! Not too many flavors to choose from but that's okay because you're sure to like all of them anyway. Very much a hole in the wall and virtually no where to sit and enjoy your ice cream once you get it and the place is always packed!
author: Kaelee M.

description: Definitely a must try! This different concept of them freezing the ice cream that u select and then rolling in front of you. I think it's an experience more than anything. Toppings are unlimited & rolled ice cream itself is delicious. I've been here a couple times already and they never fail to fullfill my sweet tooth. Its a first come first serve basis. On hot days just expect to wait a little over 30 mins for your ice cream for it does get reallly packed and buzy.
author: Len A.

description: We got the 3 berry flavor which has vanilla, strawberry, raspberry, and blueberry. There are unlimited toppings. We got whipped cream, mochi, lychee jelly, and strawberries. It was extremely creamy and delicious. The ice cream is made super flat and then rolled into rolls. Good service. No tables. Just these benches. Pretty crowded.
author: Amanda L.

description:
I loved the funky monkey!! The price is a little bit high, and the wait is a bit of a wait, but when I finally got to try it out, it was all worth it. I don't live in the area but I am definitely going to bring back some family to try this treat! 

The rolls didn't melt easily and it had a really dense, yet smooth texture. Watching them make it was also a treat. Don't be afraid to ask tips on the toppings, especially if you're not familiar with getting toppings on those flavors.

I am definitely coming back, and I wish they were open 24/7 LOL
author: bcast b.

description:
1st time here and I ordered the "Cookie Monster" w/ free toppings! 

*Friendly servers
author: Wendy L.

description:
Nice hand roll ice cream with unlimited toppings!!!
Great variety of ice cream and toppings! If you don't mind the crowd and wait, this is the place to come. Just not the cleanest place.
author: Shirley Y.

description:
It was my first time trying a thai-chee flavor ice cream and it was pretty good. 

However, when this girl worker noticed that someone (me) had ordered the thai ice cream, she complained about my order to her coworker. Saying she did not like making it, it's too sticky, etc. It was just unpleasant to hear when I was the one who ordered it and isn't one of the unique flavor here the "Thai Ice cream"? 

While we were waiting for the ice cream to be made, they were just chi-chatting and seemed like there isn't 10 people waiting for their ice cream.
author: Anna L.

description: Rolled ice cream is the trendiest thing right now. The ice cream is really aesthetic and the portions are quite large. I would recommend sharing with another person. When I came here, I got the Thai Chee flavored. Not a lot of places have Thai tea flavored ice cream so I wanted to give it a try here. The ice cream was good, but not good enough for me to be hooked. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if i was around the area, I would reconsider coming here again. There is a long wait for your ice cream since it is not as simple as scooping it out of a tub. On a Saturday night after dinner, I had to wait around 25 minutes and there is not a lot of waiting room since the shop is a small place. I'm a rather simple person and would prefer going elsewhere with better service and not pay $7 for rolled ice cream. Overall, i'm glad i gave this place a try.
author: Steph L.

description:
I'm really torn about 3 or 4 stars, because honestly I don't want to be mean. 

I had the Cookie Monster with strawberries. 
Ordering was a bit overwhelming because the menu was cluttered on the sandwich blackboard. There wasn't much direction on how to order for first timers. I would recommend simplifying the process as well as including photos of toppings or something other than that simple writing on a board because there's just so much to choose from. I am sure a lot of people get excited about unlimited toppings. And the worst part, the server didn't have a smile or did he make any recommendations. I was so overwhelmed I only got strawberries and my friend got nothing. I mean great for the owners, but a poor experience for two new customers. I would also recommend different sizes because quiet honestly I don't want to spend $7 on a cup of ice cream that isn't even made in house with fresh and organic products etc,etc (you get the picture). Plus maybe invest a bit more time cleaning the floor mid-day from squished fruit on the ground, crumbs on the seats, a better spot for the recycle bin and possibly a compost bin! (San Francisco does cite for improper disposal of waste.) 

The Cookie Monster was good. I like the bits of crunch for texture. Overall, it isn't $7 good. 

After all this, I would definitely stick to a 3 star review.
author: Jess W.

description:
Came on a nice, sunny day in SF around 2:45PM. Along with myself and 3 others, we encountered a decent long line that took about 10-15 minutes. Having tried rolled ice cream previously at Icicles in San Jo, I was very excited to bring my mom and sister to try rolled ice cream for the first time locally and with a menu listed on the menu we decided amongst 4 flavors: Master Ube, Strawberry Cheescake, 3x Berry, and Mo'cha Matcha. Inconvenient enough, they did not have master ube so we had to suffice with Cookie Monster AND we got a Mo'cha Matcha but they didn't have mochi toppings at all! Someone please explain to me why it's called "Mo'cha".

Each cup with unlimited toppings called for $6.50 a piece; spent about $28 including tax. Our number was #81 and they called out #63 once we got out of line so we knew we would be here for a while. All in all, we waited in line for 1hr 45 min. I honestly believe the reason it takes very long compared to other rolled ice cream places is their lack of # employees. Having 6 employees on a busy day is not enough and gets very tiring for the rollers!

I suggest that while the cashier takes down the order he has a nice amount of cups enough to pause with the next guest in order to prep the cup and help out the other employees so the line won't go by as quick and the wait for the product itself wouldn't take as long.

We had a bit of an additional hold up, however, when our four cups of ice cream did not come out at the same time. The third cup was taken by the employee and came out 10 minutes later than the fourth cup had its toppings. We were very aggravated and disappointed by the lack of reassurance that the ice cream will come out on time. When we tried to inform the workers, we got ignored multiple times and were never appreciated with an apology for the wait. By the time we got out ice cream, the next cup to be asked for toppings was #91(mind you we were #81). I appreciate the time and effort for the workers and understand it is a tiring job but some reassurance or decency to inform the customers that the wait would increase is just a prime factor of customer service. 

For the product itself, the ice cream was very decent tasting but I wish they had more toppings such as mochi and tapioca. Some rolls were very sloppy once put inside the cup and toppings are very limited quantity. For myself, I got the strawberry cheesecake and I really enjoyed the cream taste in it. I included toppings with crushed ghram cracker, crushed Oreos, condensed milk, strawberries, raspberries, & whipped cream(must try!) I appreciate the place itself and despite the wait, I will come back again just to have my cup of local rolled ice cream.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
I been wanting to try rolled ice cream since I watched all those ice cream videos from Taiwan  a few years back. Then it finally came to the Bay Area and I couldn't resist. Apparently everyone else heard about their arrival too because the wait here is very long. 

 I came here on a Friday night around 9am and it took a total of 30mins from the time that I ordered until I got my order. Pretty long wait to get your ice cream but it's understandable considering the amount of work that needs to be done to make it. The place is overall really small, and with the large amount of people waiting for their orders, it was also very humid inside. 

What I liked about this place is that they have a good variation of ice cream combos. I got the Thai Chee, which was Thai Ice cream with lychee bits mashed into it. Overall the ice cream was less creamy that regular ice cream (makes sense since they don't get churned or anything) and I appreciate that they have unlimited free toppings. (Let's be honest here, most places will charge for every little thing)

TLDR; Good experience, more on the expensive side (~$7 for one order), good combos and unlimited toppings, long wait.
author: Jenny N.

description:
My friend and I came around 3:30 and we got our ice cream pretty fast. Waited around 5-10. Pretty decent considering there were only two people rolling those ice creams.

I got a thai chee. They used real lychee to mix with the thai ice cream and my friend got strawberry cheesecake. She said the thaichee has a more unique flavor than hers.

Next time I'll try the cookie monster or the oreo one! Btw, they give you free AND unlimited toppings. Good good
author: Kathy D.

description: First time trying it. It's actually pretty good. Portions are big so it's good to share. Love the unlimited toppings. It does take at lease 15-20 min to get your ice cream since it's made when order. Not a good place if your in a rush. Limited seatings.
author: Christy V.

description: It's good. I definitely prefer another hyped up ice cream shop similar to Let's Roll. Four stars for the flavor but I didn't like the fact that they don't fill our cup up with more ice cream.
author: Jennifer L.

description: My family was visiting San Francisco when we came here, and even though we only have one experience with Let's Roll, it was pretty great. When we walked in, there weren't too many people, so we got our orders really fast. The flavors we picked were Cookie Monster, Master Ube, and Matcha-cha, and they were all fantastic! None of the flavors were too sweet, and the toppings were definitely a plus. Needless to say, we're going to remember this place the next time we're in town.
author: Bri M.

description:
The rolled up ice cream was on my list to try since I saw Thailand's vendor doing it on a YouTube video. I finally get to follow this trend. 

My thoughts: ehh....
Concept and toppings were fun. The drawbacks are: 1) ice cream is too sweet for the banana and Nutella...they need to cut sugar in the cream or amount of chocolate, and 2) the person needs to thin out the rolls more. Too thick to eat. 

Overall the concept was fun and combo flavors seem fun but it's too sweet and thick ice cream. 

Side note: all the flavors are pre-made liquid. They just add the fruits and what not like cold stone.
author: Linda C.

description: My friend and I ordered it for delivery. The ice cream arrived quickly which was great and the rolls were nicely made. The only thing I didnt like was the fact that the ice cream used is more of the artificially flavored kind.
author: Ernest M.

description:
Pro-tip: Order at the register, and do not come here for the rolled ice cream if you are in a rush, as it could take 20-30 minutes to get your order if there are more than 5 people in the store. While we waited, we noticed one patron cancel an order because of the wait. I wish the cashier told us the anticipated wait time since it is pretty ridiculous to wait 20+ minutes for ice cream after you pay. 

We had the thai-chee (thai tea and lychee) rolled ice cream, which had good flavor. Though it was a large serving suitable for two people, it was expensive and not worth the wait. 

I know this place is new, but their service was extremely inefficient. If you get the rolled ice cream, they put your name on a cup with a rollerball pen that smears, and then the employees have no idea who ordered what flavor. The cashier would disappear and leave customers in line waiting to order. The employee who adds toppings would walk all the way to the back of the shop for a single strawberry. It all leads me to think that there must be a better way to operate. 

If we ever come back, it will be for a quick scoop.
author: CQ N.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night around 8pm with my girlfriends. They've been open for a few weeks but didn't have rolled ice cream until 3 days ago. We wanted to beat the rush before this place blows up on social media. There wasn't much of a wait, probably because this is still fairly new. It was my first time having rolled ice cream and I LOVED it. One of my friends had tried the one in New York, and another one had tried the one in San Jose prior to this, but they both liked this place more. 

Service: 5 Stars! Their rolled ice cream is good but the service I experienced last night made the experience even better. The owners and employees were super friendly, and one of them told us that he grew up in SF. I love helping out local businesses since I grew up in the city myself. The girl that made my ice cream was super friendly and didn't get annoyed at all when my friends and I took a while deciding on our toppings. Instead, she helped us narrow down our decisions and even tossed out some suggestions. I felt like I was talking to a friend instead of dealing with customer service. They also gave my entire group of friends (there were 5 of us) one free stamp on our stamp card! SO NICE. 

Rolled Icecream: We shared the Cookie Monster and the 3x Berry (Strawberry, Blueberry, Raspberry). Both flavors were delicious. The vanilla base that they used for our ice cream had a slight malt taste which personally I am a huge fan of. I love malt! The berry flavor was refreshing and not too overwhelming. I love that they use fresh fruit and combine the ingredients in front of your eyes. When they're done rolling your ice cream, you can add as many toppings as you want - whaaat?! So awesome. 

At first I thought $6-7 was a little pricey for an order of ice cream but when you think about the service and the effort that goes into it, it makes sense. The portions are fair - I recommend sharing with a friend(s) because I think it would have been too much for me to finish by myself (unless I had an empty stomach).  

Definitely looking forward to my next visit here. Excited to try the other flavors!
author: Annie L.

description:
Let's roll! 

The ice cream was good but not the best. I still prefer scooped ice cream. It took a pretty long time for us to get the ice cream since it's such a new spot, everyone was here and we had to wait for 10 orders to finished before they start to make ours. 

Food quality: matcha mocha ice cream is alright, not creamy and lacking a rich favor. It felt like a watery based ice cream. And the options of toppings are okay, they don't give a heavy amount of toppings, just a light sprinkle and one cookie or two pockie sticks. 

Service: the service is good, overall everyone was friendly and the place was kept pretty clean and open. Just the fact that there were so many ppl, it was very overwhelming and time consuming. 

Overall experience was good! Recommend ppl to try this type of ice cream and see if it is something you like personally. For me, I will come back and try another favor. 

Tip: see what other ppl order, if you see a popular favor, order that, you can't go wrong with that!!!
author: Joanne C.

description:
Don't be deceived. Concept is cool but this place is a no go. You wait so long for your ice cream and when you get it, it's too cold to even eat right away. 

By the time you are able to eat it, the ice cream is no longer in its "roll" form. Might as well just get a scoop of ice cream somewhere else and ditch the long line. A for effort but 1 star for execution and waiting.
author: Michele P.

description:
Rushed from Yummy Yummy to go to Let's Roll before it closed at 9. 

We weren't sure where the line was, but was then greeted by the cashier who told us to order there. The layout is kind of confusing because people are in line watching their ice cream being made but they already paid for it, rather than pay for it after it's made. 

The menu isn't super intuitive either because you can order set items, like the Cookie Monster, which says it comes with Whip Cream and Oreo Cookie as toppings, but then you can add whatever topping you want. So maybe a sign that says Unlimited Toppings or something. 

The ice cream itself was very frozen and thick, but it does make it melt at a slower pace, so you can enjoy it for longer. Just don't try to dig in too quick. Feels like you can break the spoon. 

The thick, kind of sticky texture to it is pretty unique. Not sure if I prefer it over creamier, lighter ice cream. 

Overall it's kind of pricey, but specially made ice cream is expected to be so. The service is really nice and I can see the effort they put into making the ice cream.
